company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Good Job for Experience
pros:
-People are usually kind (minimal yelling)
-People care about helping the work progress- I like knowing that I am making a difference
-The company generally splurges on good software
-Good health care and benefits
-You will learn a lot because there is a lot to be done
cons:
-Sexism (I have been asked multiple times when I'm going to have kids, and my manager told me that a co-worker told him not to hire me because I would just take maternity benefits and leave... I've worked here for five years and also can't have kids, so that has been a real struggle.)
-Overworking- for a period of about six months, I worked 50-70 hour weeks because two people on my team quit. It took more than six months for management to hire replacements, so I was expected to do the work of three people and was constantly berated for not getting things done. Overtime is expected because it is the Lord's work. I took a day and a half of leave last week for the first time in half of a year and was made to feel super guilty about it, someone literally said, "glad YOU had a break!" to me.
-Poor pay and advancement- Do not expect your job to keep up with inflation, no matter how many hours you put in and no matter how hard you work. The people who determine raises do not know you, and the pay-raise process is archaic. Do not expect to ever be able to advance if you are in any kind of technical field. I've been told that I was "absolutely crucial to my team" and "had done so much" and then given a 2% raise ("the highest in the department!") from what I was told.
-Fudging Numbers and general dishonesty- I've been asked for data on multiple occasions where the results did not look pretty and was then accordingly told to show it a different way or cut off a couple months' worth of data at the end of a graph. Nobody cares about your opinion or being honest, they just want to look good.
-Split technology department- ICS and church employees don't work well together; because of the contract model, there are many crucial datasets built with Jenga tiles. Models are built really hastily, are rarely documented, and then they are abandoned as the people who built them simply leave because their contract ended.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: It's gone downhill the last few years
pros: Some rare opportunities can pop up where you're able to contribute to really meaningful projects. Most people really develop great relationships with other coworkers on their teams.
cons: Department management is super unqualified to do their job and are completely out of touch. Finance and budget is really screwy and it messes with project deadlines and destroys creativity. For some reason within the last few years, management has decided it's time to downsize (not based on any actual data) but because they've "felt impressed" to do so. They even told us, "we predict that the work load over the next year is going to significantly decrease. so in order to prepare for that, we're going to let all of our outsource contracts expire. our current workforce should be enough to handle that reduced load." Then into the next year the workload more than doubled. They essentially said, "oops sorry. we kinda goofed on that one. But no we're not going to hire additional employees to help with the workload. " In fact, as more and more people leave, most of those positions are not being backfilled. Budget cuts are everywhere. No more professional development. No more offsites. No more travel. No more team lunches. And when employees leave, their spots are not backfilled. All-hands meetings are a complete joke and are extremely demotivating because of the shocking lack of awareness our management team has of what's going on in the department. This is the most siloed organization I have ever seen. It's absolutely full of territorialism, backbiting, ladder climbing, and ridiculous politics. Product management constantly plays what many like to call "general authority poker" where a project's priority is not determined by the actual researched needs of members throughout the world, but how many general authorities the PMs can "sell" their product ideas to. (I've seen this happen first hand btw and it's disgusting.) Our department sends out workforce surveys all the time, and even reports back to us on what the most common points of feedback are. Yet no changes are ever made. If you work here, you will be ignored, you will be undervalued, and you will most likely never see any of your work go anywhere.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Mixed Experience
pros:
- Helping in the mission of the Church is great
- Generally nice people
- Sometimes there is free food
- Two ping pong tables, gym, bike storage, good locker room, etc.
- The Church is generally recognized by other companies as a great place to learn, some good training goes on for the most part.
cons:
- Some people don't care to get to know you, or talk to you, or explain stuff to you. I sat with a team for months and never really got to know any of them, despite efforts to strike up conversations. They just come in, type and leave. 
- I often found out I was doing work that is typically someone else's job, but no one ever took the time to explain everyone's role on the team. This is related to the above point. And yes, I asked for clarification a few times, but was not given sufficient explanation.
- The contingent model (contract workers) is a bit wacky. I was told that if/when I leave, I would be backfilled, and yet there is no opportunity to go from contract worker (2 year max) to a full time employee. This leads to lots of entry -mid level turnover and retraining.
- In many ways, it seems a bit like a personality contest. I moved teams several times due to "budget issues" which I won't deny were there, but could have been easily worked out (and when I switched teams, another replaced me). I think it stemmed more from a partner and I not able to relate to each other more than capability of doing the job.
- Some managers are really great, caring and trusting. Others won't give the time of day, make no effort to get to know you, and are a bit out of touch with you, your work and team.

There is no single leader to push directives and hold the entire Corporation accountable, so initiatives fracture, are modified, and fail.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Global Service Center - Good starting into the IT industry. Bad overall position.
pros:
If you're new to the IT industry with some background, you'll have a chance to get hired in. 
Church has good benefits. 
Nice people to work with. 
Compared to most call centers, you're working with members of the church. Seldom do you get distressed/upset employees calling in.
cons:
I came in as a part-time employee seeking full-time employment. I was looked at favorably to be promoted quickly but after a seasoned manager "left" my fate was left up to the politics of hiring with the new managers of the team. Which were, they favored married individuals, with families, school, etc over individuals who were just single such as myself. I saw this time and time again where I would have more time and experience at the GSC and was still placed second behind that group. Management is new so their hiring skills are rather incompetent. I was micromanaged and it was unpleasant. I felt undervalued and my work unappreciated. I felt management didn't care about me as an individual. Feedback was poor and did not help me improve in any way. Even after I had made the changes they requested, they did pay any attention.  I was looking forward to continue working for the church, I took a massive pay and time cut but clearly that didn't matter to them. When management had changed, people were realizing they could go elsewhere with a better environment. Employees were dropping faster than they could hire. We were moving into the "Slow season" and I was constantly on calls the moment I got in and we were scolded if we took too long of breaks or lunches or heaven forbid work on a ticket a little longer, yet they failed to hire more employees. 
Food is way overpriced, and there is nowhere else to get food unless you want to jog to crown burger and be late anyway. 
The hours were bad for me, I could only work 28 hours a week and was traveling long distances. There are only a few slots per team that are allowed full-time. About 15 or so per team and around 3 individuals per team get full-time. I won't go back to the GSC.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Excellent Employer
pros: I have worked for the church for many years at headquarters in Salt Lake City. I *really* like the work and the work environment and the people. The church is very competitive with salary and benefits. The health insurance through DMBA is especially generous--better than any large employer I am aware of. On-site gym and health center (and cafeteria) at downtown Salt Lake City campus. 401k matching. Maternity leave (7 weeks). Inexpensive UTA train and bus passes. On-site parking, free (including a lot of covered parking). Every department potentially has a different culture and not every manager or situation is ideal, but overall people are trying to work hard and be kind and do quality work. company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Publishing Services Department 2018
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Honestly, the pay is pretty good. Department management is MUCH better than it was 2+ years ago. But under the new managing director, all of the second level management are the same folks who have been around for years.
cons:
Change is touted as a constant, but it never results in visible improvements. There is a flavor of the day mentality that long time employees have seen for many, many years. Major process and tool changes happen annually. Major reorganizations happen every few years. Significant layoffs happen about every 5 years. Tons of folks are hired as contracted ESG or Nexeo employees with an implied promise that if they work hard and do well, they'll be hired on full time. We spend tons of time and money training them and incorporating them into critical roles, and then we let them go when their contract expires.

Communication in the department was terrible under previous management, and is better now, but still not great. There is still intense fear of losing one's job, even among full time employees. There is still enormous ambiguity around the most recent initiative to reorganize and simplify. And there is still a feeling that the old "regime" is mostly still in place.

People see that certain managers bounce around from position to completely unrelated position about every year, and they aren't leaving wild successes in their wake. At best, they seem to be average managers. What are employees supposed to think when there are free spirits who can apparently change their job whenever they feel like it, but they are always involved in high level initiatives and discussions? There is a feeling of favoritism, and if you're not on the list, you'll never make very high.

The way finances in the department are handled is messy, time consuming, and difficult. Financial information is almost always out of date, yet finance is always asking employees for more and more work to make their lives easier, rather than the other way around. We waste tons of time tracking and then approving billable hours.

The listing here on Glassdoor is terribly misleading. Every department is wildly different in how it is run and its goals and management. President Nelson has very little to do with the day-to-day work of most departments, so rating him gives a skewed impression of the workplace.

I could go on and on, but I'll cut this short here.

My coworkers destroyed others everyday, they made everyone look bad to upper management and shifted the blame to others whenever they could. I tried to tell management what was happening but my team would come back and blame me and say its my problem and to deal with it. It was such an abusive environment. I also feel bad for my friends in other departments who experienced horrible trauma, one even said working for the church was a lot worse than going through divorce.

Also, management often doesn't to want to hear input, and it is insanely difficult to get paid even the average/normal wage for your skill sets. Its frustrating to hear you get blessed in other ways for taking a steep pay cut while you're struggling to make ends meet. 

People often don't like talking about these events at the church office because it often affects others negatively and impacts their view of the church, but this isn't uncommon. I was surprised so many people warned me prior to working there. The church itself is good, but the corporate side can be a mess sometimes.

pros: The benefits are fantastic. The compensation is fair for the market, though not particularly high. Basically, it's good for a single person, but it would be tough to support a family on it. Still, you generally do get at least a small raise every year, which is nice. In general, most people are really nice. The work was very interesting and I had a lot of autonomy to make decisions. Also, the building facilities and workplace equipment were first class - very nice workspace, etc. The flexible hours were great, too.
cons:
There's not much opportunity for advancement, particularly not for women. The vast majority of managers and directors are men. HR is making some efforts to change this, but there is still little opportunity to advance or be promoted even outside of the management track. 
Workplace bullying and harassment is an issue and is not taken seriously enough. The bullies and harassers are allowed to stay on because it's so difficult to fire people, while those who are bullied (women) end up quitting to get away from the bullies. 
Telecommuting is technically against company policy, but some employees were allowed to do it all the time whereas others were only occasionally allowed to do it and still others were not allowed to at all. This needs to be allowed on a fair and reasonable basis. 
Also, the rule that women have to wear skirts is antiquated and, let's be honest, sexist. Dress slacks should be allowed. (In fairness, HR has been trying to get this rule changed, but it's coming from the top.)

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: The Global Service Center (of disappointment)
pros: There are a few pros. Number one being the benefits package. The benefits package is one of the best in the market! And that's why people stay. The location is also nice. It's close to trax and the frontrunner. Last but not the least, I really liked working with people who shared the same values as me.
cons:
There are so many more downsides than there are pros. First, there are no opportunities for advancement.  I've been here for almost five years and I'm in the same position as when I started and it's not like I don't try. I've applied many, many times. Second, the corporate culture is something to frown upon. If you don't fit the typical Utah Mormon mold, best of luck to you.  Prepare for some scrutiny. There's no professional development here. Also, they don't offer any onsite perks. You just work, work, work, work, and work. Management also never shows appreciation for their employees. There is NO autonomy and you are not allowed to make your own decisions. Your breaks are timed and if you go over just ONE MINUTE, you'll be reported. If you go on the internet while on your shift, you will be reported. They also keep track of how much time you spend off the phones. If you're not busy enough, they'll give you a "Subject Matter Expert TASK" like training other people, doing quality assurance on calls, writing instructions (technical writing) but for no additional pay. BUT, taking calls is your FIRST priority. There is no sort of flexibility in your schedule. You are expected to live and breathe work. 

There's an overwhelming amount of things to do on a day-to-day basis.

But perhaps the most disappointing thing about this place is, they don't practice what they preach. Employees are expected to treat work like church and are expected to "lead like the savior," but management treats us all like we're disposable. The turnover here is quite high, because if you had other options, why would you stay in a place that makes you feel like you're nothing? The people who end up staying are those who have no other choice. This place doesn't tend to keep "the best" talent. Instead, it tends to keep those who have nowhere else to go--which says a lot about the corporate culture they've cultivated here.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: IT Department: Labor of Love....and Painful Growth
pros: Salaries have improved in ICS IT Department. You work for the greatest purpose in the world, very satisfying. There are many opportunities to unite with like-minded people to a common cause. There is an strong internal demand for IT services and a wide variety of modern technologies deployed to meet them. There are many challenges but if you keep a positive attitude you will grow in amazing ways. Training is available and valued.
cons: Currently the HR function in ICS is totalitarian and is creating an atmosphere of fear, distrust, and nearly a hostile work environment. Truly unfortunate, because it hasn't always been that way. Things turned bad after new HR leadership arrived.  Also heavily reliant on contract labor, which unfortunately are limited to one-year contracts with one year option to renew. These "contingents" can sometimes be unintentional treated as second-class citizens, which can be demoralizing. I feel bad for them. Legacy IT environments are big, complex, and enterprise architecture is nearly anarchic. The organization itself is so big and bureaucratic that change can be excruciatingly slow and political landmines are everywhere, just like any big organization. Since open hostility is not well tolerated in the Church culture, passive aggressiveness is common.  There is very little upward mobility, attrition in the top IT management is very low, and moderate in the middle management, which is telling. Attrition of top technical talent is also a big issue as the local job market has heated up.

headline: It is Garbage
pros: We have pretty good benefits, which I believe is the main reason that many people stay here. I don't need to use my brain very often so I can listen to a lot of good podcasts while working. If you are a yes-man, never want to question "authority", and you really like those short feel-good church propaganda videos, then you will probably enjoy it here and most likely thrive.

-Very political and hostile environment where everyone has their own agenda and are not afraid to back stab. 
-Terrible leadership that definitely does not practice what they preach. 
-A lot of judging among peers and people are very unfriendly towards each other.  
-Very little vacation time. 
-Mandatory shutdowns where you have to use 8 or 9 of your 12 annual vacation days on certain times of the year when they choose.
-Not very much trust and delegation, but a whole lot of micro-managing.

-Sometimes your job is treated like a job and other times its treated like a church calling depending on what they want from you.  
-You will get thrown into a new assignment or job with no training or pay raise and are expected to perform like you are a trained professional.
-Poor communication all around.  
-A lot of unethical people doing unethical things, which is very shocking when you expect working for the church to be a spiritual experience.  
-Lack of integrity in the way things are done. 
-Most people I know here don't really enjoy their jobs but everyone is afraid to speak up because of how they have treated others who have done so before.
-Because it is a church run business, people won't speak up or verbally oppose leadership because it is seen as opposing the church itself, so people can get away with a lot. 
-The lunch room is like a prison where everyone is divided up into their ethnicity "gangs". 
-Expectations are too high for the amount you are paid. 
-A lot of blaming others instead of taking responsibility.
-If you give your opposing opinion, people are not afraid to turn on you on a dime with no compassion or love.

The pay is also quite reasonable and comparable to industry standards for many positions- and there seem to be opportunities for advancement, at least for those who are most loyal to the organization.

Women and minorities seem to be very underrepresented in leadership positions.

pros: I absolutely love working with people who shared my values. I also liked the location, because it's walking distance from trax.

So.many.cons.

I've never cried at work until I came to this place. Working here has truly taken away my faith in humanity. Here's why:

1) They micromanage you TO THE BONE! I'm talking, we have daily "priority" checklists. PLUS, we are required to report an hourly breakdown of our days.

3) toxic work environment
2) crappy hours

4) management's unwillingness to work with your school schedule. if you're a student, forget this place. you'll never be done with your degree! Then, you'll be stuck here forever. (I've seen it happen...)
5) You'll be taken advantage of. And let me elaborate--you're hired as a customer service representative but they give you "Subject Matter Expert tasks." That means, you could be writing knowledge base articles, doing quality assurance for calls, training new people. And all of that for NO pay increase. 
6) They will bombard you with things to do. So many things to do--all the time! And when you don't do them, management sends out nasty emails about you wasting the lord's money.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Be careful what department you go and work for.
pros:
There is a sense of purpose in knowing your work is making a difference to the World.  I have worked in different departments in the Church and in some areas, there is a good camaraderie and sense of purpose.  

The benefits are excellent; you'd be hard pressed to find across the board benefits as rich.  

The monetary compensation is typically low market although there are some exceptions.  The salaries are more competitive with entry level people and grow a pretty sizable delta with more experienced hires.
cons:
I wouldn't work in ICS (Information and Communications Services) no matter what right now.  The environment of the whole group, especially in HR is pretty toxic.  HR drives many of the decisions both overtly and behind the scenes and they aren't that savvy to be able to do that. They seem way more interested in their own power and legacy than doing what is best for the business.   They make it pretty obvious they have the power to fire individuals or reorg the group at their whim and even leadership is afraid to challenge them.  As a result the directors often seem uncertain or schizophrenic in their decisions.  It is extraordinarily political and often who you know and are friends with is more important than what you can do.  It is pretty clear to most that employees are viewed as a commodity that can be discarded or at least have their role minimized at a moment's notice.

Outside of that one department, I believe the management to be much more open to different ideas and supportive of individual success.

Generally in the whole Church, it is extraordinarily difficult to get a raise or promotion outside of the typical cost of living increase each year.  (They do call it a merit increase, but it seems to have little to do with merit.)

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Secure Job w/Opportunities for Growth if...
pros: Great benefits. Inspiring cause - it's fun to work on products that benefit and sometimes completely change peoples' lives. Fascinating to see how products come about and take part in councils and strategizing sessions. Compensation for lower and middle management is fair to above average. Secure job. Opportunities for growth if you work hard, network outside your portfolio, and pay attention. Pleasantly surprised by several managers and supervisors who have gone above and beyond to mentor me, give me opportunities, push me out of my comfort zone and generally assist in career development as a working mom (this shouldn't be a shocker, I know, but it is given the patriarchal nature of the Church). Work-life balance is great and family life is respected and supported.
cons: No paid maternity leave so I had to use all my vacation and sick leave and came back to work after three weeks. Pay is fine though once you negotiate salary, promotions are difficult to get and yearly increases average 2-3%. Difficult to get rid of underperformers. Highly political atmosphere. Not as open to gathering data before a project starts and feedback once it's in production as one would hope. Still pretty top-down approach to product development ("we know what the customer needs" vs. "let's find out what the customer needs") but there are pockets of hope.

Raising people out of poverty, spreading hope and peace through the gospel of Jesus Christ, teaching people about who they are, where they came from, and what is the purpose of this life -- if your beliefs coincide, its a great organizational mission to get behind. Great work-life balance. Compensation in I.T. jobs is about average with the industry.

In the tech space, the Church has come a long way over the past 5 years.
cons: Most tech opportunities center around the Church offices in Riverton, UT or in Salt Lake City. Non-profit culture can be a bit slow.

pros: Similar values and purpose with a real commitment to the work.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: One of the best two years I've ever spent in my life
pros: It helps you to learn to have faith in yourself and to organize yourself. When you take the action to achieve what you plan to do, you need to exercise your faith too. The combination of faith and action will become the most powerful tool in your life of career.

cons: There is some red tape and normal admin stuff with a big organization.  If you are okay working on a big, slow moving ship, that is okay.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

pros: High Standards, common objectives, great people that share my values. Market driven salaries and benefits that are above market. Working for a higher cause.
cons: There is a perception that salaries are lower than market.  Several layers of senior decision makers. The dress code requires suit and tie, very formal.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Great opportunity to work in the Lord's kingdom
pros: As a member of the LDS Church, it is easy to be passionate about the work.  The benefits are great and there are outstanding people to work with .  It is an unique environment to begin meetings with prayer and hold devotionals.
cons: The Church is a conservative organization and like most large organizations can have its fair share of politics.  Things can often move slowly, held up by committees and leaders.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Great Place to Work!

cons: Often too heavy a workload.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: A great job, for a great cause
pros: Working on something that really matters. I love knowing that the work I do will help the gospel be taken to the world, help people come to Christ, help the poor and needy get assistance, help general authorities spend their time more productively, and ultimately save tithing dollars.
cons: Politics still exist here, like they do everywhere. But there is lots of good will to mitigate that.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Developer 1
pros: Amazing management! I have never felt more appreciated for my work, and desired to do so much better. We work as a team, because our team knows how to work hard, and how to play on each others strengths, not focus on each others weaknesses.
cons: I am too far away from work (driving distance) No complaints about work itself, simply the best place I have ever worked.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Fantastic Work Environment with a Purpose
pros:
Working for the Church is like working for a charity that doesn't need to be hyper-focused on raising money.  You know what you are working on is contributing to either a humanitarian or ecclesiastical cause, which is a great feeling.

The IT Department at the Church (the department I worked for) does a good job at staying on top of technology.  They are typically quick to adopt trends early on.

The work environment is awesome.  It may put off some, but I liked starting the work day in prayer with my co-workers.  It infused us with unity and purpose that can't be manufactured through traditional team-building exercises (we did those, too, though!).
cons:
The Church struggles to remain market competitive for IT staff.  My pay started out great, but it did not increase like it does in a for-profit company.  (That is not why I left, mind you.  They definitely take care of their employees.)

The load is a bit lighter than the average IT job.  This might be a good thing for you, but for me it was sometimes a little nerve-wracking to *not* be under the gun every now and again.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Working at the Missionary Training Center was one of the most meaningful experiences I have had.
pros:
-Great co-workers
-Meaningful work and teaching opportunities
cons: -For a student, it does require quite a time commitment, but is well worth it!

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Senior Engineer
pros: While there are negatives there are positives as well.  The environment is surprisingly very professional. Another plus are the retirement and medical benefits.
cons: There are limited opportunities for career growth.  From my experience it feels like in order to move up you must know someone.  Business change is too slow for my liking.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Overall a good place to work
pros: A workplace environment consistent with Gospel values, great benefits (particularly the generous pension, 401K and Health/Dental/Vision), understanding of family needs, the chance to work for something you believe in.
cons: Salaries are lower than in for-profit sector, HR is fragmented (improving but still fragmented), push for top tier results without top tier talent/resources. SOME will leverage faith to push for results.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Nearly perfect environment at times
pros: Incredible flexibility, project variety, independence, supportive environment, and freedom to innovate. Also has fitness center, bike room, recording room, and flex schedule. Work aligns with sense of purpose, and colleagues with similar values adds to comfortable working environment. If you're driven, you can do almost anything to align your passion with your work.
cons: Siloed departments, no enterprise authoring strategy, not enough tech writers per IT personnel. At times feels like a start-up due to autonomy given to individual groups. Has incredible potential but seems hindered by lack of coordination among various groups. It's a large organization, and has similar challenges as other large organizations.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Best place to work ever
pros: Everyone that works here is concerned with serving the Lord - not about making the most money. It is nice to work somewhere where everyone has the same values and can really focus on work and not worry about offending others. Policy decisions have all been approved by senior church leaders so there isn't too much pushback. The benefits are great and most people are wonderful to work with.

There are some people who work there who are probably replacable, but because they have been there for a certain amount of time they company endures having them even when their work is not up to par. company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Nice work environment, dead end career path.
pros: The people are the best reason for working here.  Working with these professionals towards a common goal is very rewarding.  The pay is good depending on experience, benefits are great and the dress code is business casual.
cons: The lackadaisical HR department is the biggest con.  Promotions for engineers are rare, random and it is common knowledge that leaving and coming back is the only direct route for obtaining the next career level.  That is true unless you take the management route, which does have a career path with frequent promotions caused by reorganization opportunities.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
headline: Good cause, mean culture
pros: Good benefits, good technology, good cause.

Burn out at the director level is astronomical.  No one remains reporting the the CIO for very long.  They never met a problem that a re-org couldn't solve.   Very unstable and schizophrenic organization in IT.  No one knows what makes the CIO happy, and he never is.

company: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
